bioghist.p: Many members of the Peters family were active in public life in Pennsylvania. The family owned the Belmont mansion and the adjoining Mantua Farms. William Peters (1702-1789) was Secretary of the Pennsylvania Land Office. His brother, Richard Peters (1704-1776), was a clergyman, Provincial Secretary, and a councilor. Richard Peters (1744-1828) was the son of William Peters, and was a judge and a farmer. Richard Peters (1779-1848), son of Judge Richard Peters, was the fourth Reporter of Decisions of the United States Supreme Court. His sister, Sarah Robinson Peters, 1785-1850, was for many years mistress of the family's Belmont mansion.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of family papers of the Peters family, many of them relating to the estate and Belmont mansion. Materials include: Sarah Robinson Peters papers related to settlement of her father's estate; Richard Peters papers related to the settlement of the family estate, including correspondence from attorney Thomas Cadwalader (Henry J. Williams, Thomas Biddle, and Eli Kirk Price were involved as attorneys for the estate); and letters, accounts, and diaries of Richard Peters. The collection also includes a letter from William Peters to Mr. Scull, Deputy Surveyor.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
